Tension-type headaches_1:
Patient Description 1:
A 35-year-old graphic designer, known to have a sedentary lifestyle due to long hours of computer work, presented with recurrent headaches. The patient described a persistent, dull, and aching head pain, often accompanied by a sensation of tightness across the forehead and in the neck and shoulder muscles. These episodic tension-type headaches, lasting from several hours to a few days, have been occurring for the past six months, with an average frequency of 2-3 episodes per week. The pain was rated as 6/10 on the severity scale. The patient noted increased sensitivity to light during these episodes. No recent pattern change or unusual features were reported. Previous self-medication with over-the-counter analgesics provided minimal relief. There is no significant medical history of note. The diagnostic evaluation will focus on further characterizing the tension-type headaches and exploring suitable treatment strategies.
Tension-type headaches_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 45-year-old individual with a history of chronic stress and long work hours in a high-pressure job presented with a persistent headache concern. The patient described a continuous, dull, aching head pain, often accompanied by a sensation of tightness and pressure across the forehead and at the back of the head. These chronic tension-type headaches have been ongoing for over six months and typically last for several hours each day, with reported pain levels averaging at 5/10 in intensity. The individual also expressed tenderness in the scalp, neck, and shoulder muscles. Despite the use of various self-management techniques and lifestyle modifications, the headaches persist. There have been no sudden pattern changes or unusual features in the symptoms. The patient's medical history is unremarkable. The diagnostic assessment will aim to further characterize the chronic tension-type headaches and explore suitable treatment options.
Tension-type headaches_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 28-year-old patient, working in a noisy industrial environment, presented with recurrent, episodic headaches. The individual reported dull, aching head pain, often accompanied by a sensation of tightness or pressure across the forehead and on the sides of the head. These tension-type headaches occur episodically, with an average frequency of 2-3 times per week, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days. The pain was rated at 7/10 in intensity during episodes. Additionally, the patient noted increased sensitivity to both light and sound. There were no sudden pattern changes or unusual features observed in the headaches. The patient has no significant medical history, and over-the-counter pain medications have provided only temporary relief. The diagnostic assessment will focus on further characterizing the tension-type headaches and exploring suitable treatment interventions for a work environment with high noise exposure.
